turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Hola, amgio. Problemas de llanta? [Hey, friend. Tire problems?]

turns.speaker: ELADIO
turns.text: No hay de que. Tengo otra. [No problem, I've got another.]

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: What's in the back?

turns.speaker: ELADIO
turns.text: Not much, jefe. Some watermelons.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I heard somebody been haulin' wets on this road.

turns.speaker: ELADIO
turns.text: I haven't seen anybody doing that.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: This same person been bragging all over the county how he don't have to cut that big gringo Sheriff in on it-- he can run his own operation 'thout any help. Como se llama, amigo?

turns.speaker: ELADIO
turns.text: Eladio Cruz.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You know this road got a bad reputation, Eladio--

turns.speaker: ELADIO
turns.text: Reputation?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Bandidos, Injuns--

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: There's many an unfortunate soul been ambushed out on this stretch. Hope you're carrying some protection.

turns.speaker: ELADIO
turns.text: Protection?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You carryin' a firearm, son?  Don't lie to me now.

turns.speaker: ELADIO
turns.text: Si--tengo escopeto--just a shotgun--

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Just a shotgun, huh? Better let me take a look at that.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MERCEDES
turns.text: Donde esta? Estoy perdido--[Where are you? I'm lost--]

turns.speaker: ELADIO
turns.text: Aqui! [Here!]

turns.speaker: YOUNG MERCEDES
turns.text: No puedo ver la orilla! [I can't see the bank!]

turns.speaker: ELADIO
turns.text: Aqui! Venga por aqui! [Over here! Come this way!]

turns.speaker: YOUNG MERCEDES
turns.text: Vi a Rosaria arastrado para el corriente--[I saw Rosaria taken away by the current--]

turns.speaker: ELADIO
turns.text: No te molestas. Tenemos a ella. [Don't worry. We've got her.]

turns.speaker: ELADIO
turns.text: Como se llama? [What's your name?]

turns.speaker: YOUNG MERCEDES
turns.text: Mercedes Gonzales Ruiz.

turns.speaker: ELADIO
turns.text: Me llama Eladio Cruz--Bienvenido a Tejas. [Welcome to Texas.]

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: Es muy lindo, su coche--

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: En ingles Enrique. This is the United States. We speak English.

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: Is very beautiful, your car.

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: Good night, Enrique. She slides into the car--

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: Buenas noches, Senora Cruz. Enrique walks in the opposite direction--

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: Senora Cruz?

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: Quien es? [Who is it?]

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: Soy yo, Enrique! No tiene miedo-- [It's me, Enrique. Don't be afraid]

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: What are you doing out there? Are you crazy?

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: Hay pasado un accidente muy grave-- [There's been a bad accident--]

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: In English, Enrique. We're in the United States--

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: I have some friends who have had a accident--

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: You have somebody else out there?

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: We was by the river? And I hear my friend callin' for help, and I look and she has falling in the water--

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: Don't tell me lies, Enrique. Que paso?

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: We was crossin' the river--

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: Enrique! Quienes son estos? How could you bring them here?

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: They need help. Jaime, Anselma-- esta es mi jefa--

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: No! No puede hacer esto--[You can't do that--]

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: You think you're doing these people a favor? What are they going to do? Either they get on welfare or they become criminals--

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: No es la verdad--[That isn't true--]

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: This girl is a friend of yours?

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: Es mi novia. [She's my girlfriend.]

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: I thought you were married!

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: I am marry to the cousin of a friend-- but only to be able to live here. This is the mother of my child--

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: This girl has a child?

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: We have a daughter.

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: Tipico.

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: Rapidamente! Everybody in the world is going to see!

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: Donde vamos? [Where are we going?]

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: A casa de Porfirio Zayas. He used to be a doctor on the other side. Gunshot wounds, fixing babies--if you can pay he can handle it.

turns.speaker: ENRIQUE
turns.text: Senora, anything it costs, I can work--

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: Don't worry about it. He owes me some favors.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: "Fishbait," says Buddy, in that quiet way of his, "What you know about them tires that went missing from markets?" Fishbait thinks for a minute, then he lifts up a loose board from the porch floor and calls down into it, "C'mon out, Pooter, they caught us!"

turns.speaker: FENTON
turns.text: Buddy Deeds. He had a way.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: He known who it was onnacouna the tire tracks in the dirt from the back of the garage to where they loaded up. "Old Fishbait," he says, "never lifted a thing in this world if there was a way he could roll it."

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Sam! I was just telling a few about your old man.

turns.speaker: FENTON
turns.text: He was a unique individual.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Big day coming up--I wish we'd have thought of it while he was still living. But he went so unexpected.

turns.speaker: FENTON
turns.text: Better late than never. Korean War hero, Sheriff for near thirty years-- Buddy Deeds Memorial P--

turns.speaker: FENTON
turns.text: Every other damn thing in the country is called after Martin Luther King, they can't let our side have one measly park?

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: King wasn't Mexican, Fenton--

turns.speaker: FENTON
turns.text: Bad enough all the street names are in Spanish--

turns.speaker: FENTON
turns.text: They just wanted it to be one of theirs--

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: That's not the whole story. The Mexicans that know, that remember, understand what Buddy was for their people.  Hell, it was Mercedes over there who swung the deciding vote for him.

turns.speaker: FENTON
turns.text: Tell that one, Hollis--

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Hell, everybody heard that story a million times.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: The two of us were the only deputies back then me and Buddy--it's what-- '58--

turns.speaker: FENTON
turns.text: '57, 1 believe--

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: And the Sheriff at the time was Big Charley Wade. Charley was one of your old-fashioned bribe-or-bullets kind of Sheriffs, he took a healthy bite out of whatever moved through this county.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: "Mas cerveza por favor."

turns.speaker: FENTON
turns.text: That Buddy was a cool breeze.

turns.speaker: FENTON
turns.text: Charley Wade were known to have put a good number of people in the ground, and your daddy gets eyeball to eyeball with him.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: We made our collection at Roderick's place and that was the last anybody seen hide nor hair of him.  He went missing the next day, along with ten thousand dollars in county funds from the safe at the jail.

turns.speaker: FENTON
turns.text: Your mother was a saint.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: --but Buddy Deeds was my salvation.

turns.speaker: H.L.
turns.text: Historic occasion, isn't it?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Seems like we have another one every week.

turns.speaker: H.L.
turns.text: Jorge and his Chamber of Commerce boys got to keep things hummin'--

turns.speaker: H.L.
turns.text: That kind of talk doesn't help, Sam.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Rather have that than the ten-foot- high catfish statue--

turns.speaker: H.L.
turns.text: Which is why we need to talk to you about the new jail--just so we're all on the same page.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: We don't need a new jail.

turns.speaker: H.L.
turns.text: That's a matter of interpretation--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: We're already renting cells to the Feds for their overflow--

turns.speaker: H.L.
turns.text: Dammit, Sam, the people are concerned about crime--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: We need a drug rehab program, we need a new elementary school--

turns.speaker: H.L.
turns.text: When we backed you--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: When you backed me you needed somebody named Deeds to bump the other fella out of office.  Hey, folks--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I heard there was a bit of a fuss.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Oh, you know, the usual troublemakers. Danny Padilla from the Sentinel, that crowd.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: There was a faction pulling for that boy who was killed in the Gulf War-- Ruben--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: --Santiago.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Right. But nobody here ever noticed him till they read his name on the national news--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: That so?

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: She put it even at three to three, so as the Mayor I get to cast the tiebreaker. The older generation won't have any problem with it. They remember how Buddy come to be Sheriff, that it was all 'cause he took their part.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Never heard from him again?

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Not a peep. Buddy run the man out of town.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Oh--he come to an accommodation. Money doesn't always need to change hands to keep the wheels turning.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Look, I know you had some problems with your father, and he and Muriel-- well--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I always wondered what you Mayors do when you're not cutting ribbons.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Sam! Hey podner! You caught me playing hooky--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Floating around out here, playin' hell with them bass--play a little cards, play a little golf, drink some beer--

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Sounds great. Where do I sign up?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I haven't been out here for a while.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: You go by your old house?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Just as well. The new people just painted it some God-awful color--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: We found a body out by the Army base yesterday. Been there for a long time.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Was it Davy Crockett or Jim Bowie?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You recall if Charley Wade was a Mason?

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Charley? I believe he was. Used to go for lodge meetings over to Laredo. What's he got to do with your body?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: All it was wearing was a big old Masonic ring and a Rio County Sheriffs badge.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You don't remember anything else from that last night you saw him, do you?

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: I told the story enough times--hell, we were just in the car, he was stewing about the fight with Buddy while we drove over to Roderick Bledsoe's--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Bledso

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: He owned the colored roadhouse before Big O--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: He still living?

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: No. I think his widow's still in their place in Darktown, though.  You think it's Charley Wade, huh?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Forensics people are sure of it. You have any idea who might have put him there?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Besides my father, I mean.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: There's no call for that, Sam. Fella made himself a pile of enemies over the years.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: And Buddy was one of them.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: We got that dedication tomorrow. This is a hell of a time to be draggin' up old business.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: People have worked this whole big thing up around my father. If it's built on a crime, they deserve to know. Now I understand why you might want to believe he couldn't do it.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: And I understand why you might want to think he could.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Morning, Hollis.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Sam! Quite a do the other day. It meant a lot to folks that you said something.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You thought any more about our murder?

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: We have a murder?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Charley Wade.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: I wish I could tell you I remembered something new, but I can't.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I got an idea what happened.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Do you?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I think somewhere between Roderick Bledsoe's club and his house, Wade ran into Buddy Deeds. I think Buddy put a bullet in him, waited for him to die, threw him in the trunk of the Sheriff's car and drove him out by the Army post, I think he buried him under four feet of sand and never looked back.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: You lived in the man's house what-- seventeen, eighteen years? And you didn't get to know him any better than that?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I got to go see somebody in San Antonio today. Your memory gets any better, I'll be back tonight.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Fellas.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Hey, Sam.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Open late.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Imonna find out one way or the other.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Your father had the finest sense of justice of any man I ever met--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah, and my mother was a saint. For fifteen years the whole damn town knew he had another woman on the side. Stole ten thousand dollars to set her up in business. But hell, what's that? You got a problem? Buddy'll fix it. Facing some time in jail? Buddy'll knock half of it off-- if you do what he says, when he says. You got some business that's not exactly legal? Talk to Buddy--

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Buddy Deeds--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Buddy Deeds was a murderer.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: The three of us cleaned up and took him to the post and put him under. Can't say I was much help.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: And the ten thousand?

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Widow's benefits. He figured it would make the disappearance look better, and that Mexican gal was just scrapin' by after Charley killed her man. They didn't get hooked up till late--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Don't think the Rangers are likely to find out any more than they already have.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Word gets out who that body was, people are gonna think Buddy done it.

turns.speaker: JORGE
turns.text: We're building up tourism, Sam--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: People come here to catch bass and to get laid at the Boy's Town in Cuidad Leon--

turns.speaker: JORGE
turns.text: Sam--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You ought to put up a banner-- "Frontera, Texas: Gateway to Cut- Rate Pussy"--

turns.speaker: JORGE
turns.text: I got Eddie Richter at the Sentinel to kill that story.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: The Perdido thing?

turns.speaker: JORGE
turns.text: He agreed it wasn't exactly news--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Danny's gonna be out for blood the next time.

turns.speaker: JORGE
turns.text: There was a mandate in the last election--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: It wouldn't happen to be your construction company gonna get the bid on building this thing, would it, H.L. And Jorge, you wouldn't be thinking about a couple dozen new jobs to dangle in front of the voters--

turns.speaker: JORGE
turns.text: There isn't money allocated for that. But a jail--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Look, I'm not gonna campaign against your deal here, but if anybody asks me, I got to tell them the truth. We-- don't--need--a new jail.

turns.speaker: MARISOL
turns.text: Steve called for you.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Steve?

turns.speaker: MARISOL
turns.text: Steve. Board of Education Steve who likes you? He goes for us hot-blooded Mexican girls, I can tell.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Spanish, please. My mother would have a heart attack.

turns.speaker: MARISOL
turns.text: Your mother's family is Spanish?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Sure, they go back to Cortez. When he rode by, they were squatting in a hut cooking hamsters for dinner.

turns.speaker: MARISOL
turns.text: You got to be interested in somebody. All you do is work.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: All my mother does is work. That's how you get to be Spanish.

turns.speaker: MARISOL
turns.text: How 'bout the Sheriff?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: The Sheriff.

turns.speaker: MARISOL
turns.text: The old-high-school-heartthrob Sheriff. I thought you were crazy about each other. He's available, you're available--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I'm unmarried. I'm not available.

turns.speaker: MARISOL
turns.text: You told me one time it was true love.

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: These ones coming up are getting stupider every year.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Maybe you're just getting less patient.

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: If they're going to survive here, they have to know how to work, Elalco! Adelante! Los clientes esperan!

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Well, you hire illegals--

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: Nobody is illegal in my cafe! They've got green cards, they've got relatives who were born here--if they only had a little common sense I'd be very happy.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: If you spent a little more time training them--

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: Did you come here to tell me how to run my business?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: No. I was wondering if you'd like to take a trip down south with us. Maybe see where you grew up--

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: Why would I want to go there?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Oh, come on--you must be curious how it's changed. Amado is into this big Tejano roots thing and I've never been further than Ciudad Leon--

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: You want to see Mexicans, open your eyes and look around you. We're up to our ears in them.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Mami, how old were you when my father--

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: He was killed.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Right. When he was killed.

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: A little older than Paloma is now.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: How come you never got married again?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: There must have been somebody.

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: I was too busy.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Nobody's too busy.

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: Maybe now. It was different back then. I had this place, I was doing all the shopping, all the cooking. What do I need some chulo with grease under his nails to drink up the profit?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: I don't mean Fernando.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Mami, the first time I brought him home, those were your exact words-- "some chulo with grease under his nails."

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: I never said that.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: You made it pretty damn clear you thought he was nobody.

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: I felt that you could do better for yourself--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: What? Become a nun? You didn't want me going out with Anglos--

turns.speaker: MERCEDES
turns.text: I never said that. It was just that boy--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: "That boy"--Mami, say his name for chrissakes!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Mrs. Bledsoe?

turns.speaker: MINNIE
turns.text: That's me.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm Sheriff Deeds--

turns.speaker: MINNIE
turns.text: Sheriff Deeds' dead, honey--you just Sheriff junior.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah, that's the story of my life.

turns.speaker: MINNIE
turns.text: You ever play one of these?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I've seen 'em.

turns.speaker: MINNIE
turns.text: Well, don't ever start up on 'em, cause once you do you can't stop. I tell myself I'm gonna play just three little games after breakfast, and here I sit with half the day gone.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You mind if I ask a few questions about your husband? Roderick?

turns.speaker: MINNIE
turns.text: I won't say nothing bad about the man, but you can ask away.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: He had the club out on the old trail road--

turns.speaker: MINNIE
turns.text: We run that twenty-odd years. Give it over to Otis Payne in 1967. April.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: So you must remember Sheriff Wade.

turns.speaker: MINNIE
turns.text: Not if I can help it.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You had to deal with him in running the club.

turns.speaker: MINNIE
turns.text: Them days, you deal with Sheriff Wade or you didn't deal at all. First of the month, every month, he remind you of who you really workin' for.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: He squeezed money out of you?

turns.speaker: MINNIE
turns.text: Wasn't legal to sell liquor in a glass back then unless you was a club, see. Roderick used to say, "Buy yourself a drink, you get a free membership." But Sheriff Wade, he could shut you down anytime.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: And my father?

turns.speaker: MINNIE
turns.text: Sheriff Buddy was a different story. Long as Roderick throw his weight the right way on election day, make sure all the colored get out to vote- we was called colored back then, if you was polite--maybe throw a barbecue for the right people now and then, things was peaceful. That Sheriff Wade, though, he took an awful big bite.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: People didn't complain?

turns.speaker: MINNIE
turns.text: Not if they was colored or Meskin. Not if they wanted to keep breathin'.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Do you remember the last time you saw him?

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Pilar, is uhm--is Amado okay?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Okay? He's not here?

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: No. Is he sick?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: He's going to wish he was dead.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I don't think you can take it personally--

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: I'd like to see them spend a day pulling 14-year-olds off of each other--I should get combat pay--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I have new respect for some of my kids, meeting the parents they've been dealt--

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: I didn't understand the spot I was putting Roderick in.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: And that was the last time you saw him?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Oh--I think he came in one more time with Hollis and--naw, your Daddy wasn't with them. Made their monthly pickup. Roderick wasn't in so I just kept my mouth good and shut and handed over that envelope.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: That was the night he disappeared?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Could of been. That was white people's business.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: And when my father was Sheriff?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: What about it?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What was your deal with him?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Buddy was more a part of the big picture--county political machine, chamber of commerce, zoning board if I kept those people happy, he was pretty much on my side.  Whenever somebody thought--they start up another bar for the black  folks, they'd be--how should I put this? They'd be officially discouraged.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: He ever accept cash for a favor?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: I'm not open. We were just talking.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hollis probably told you we found Charley Wade.

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Yeah. How about that? People start digging holes in this county, there's no telling what'll come up.

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: Not if you have half a brain in your head.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Of course you can.

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: It doesn't have anything to do with being smart.

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: Mom?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: You gonna stay out here?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: For a while.

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: What's she singing about?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: She finally got in--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: It's Saturday.

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: You got in late last night.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Yeah. I had uhm--school business.

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: Can I get this?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Nobody really wears that stuff, Paloma.

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: I could name five girls at school who have one just like it--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Enough with the clothes--

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: Just 'cause you went to Catholic school and wore a uniform.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I only went for my last two years.

turns.speaker: PALOMA
turns.text: How come?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Oh, my mother wanted to keep me away from away from boys.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Morning, Sheriff.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hey, Pete. How's it going?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Time marches on.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: How much you got left?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Three months.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You stop growing that loco weed at your place, you'd see a lot more daylight.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: It was for personal consumption.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You're going to smoke an acre and a half of marijuana?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I got a bad stomach. It helps me digest.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Your father never bothered me about it. Leastways not till the drug people got on his back in the late '60s.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I thought he busted you a couple times.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Different charge. I had a still. Made my own mescal.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: That's how I ruined my stomach.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm surprised he bothered with it.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: He was afraid I was going to poison somebody. Your father tried to do good for people--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: So I've heard--

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: And your mother was a saint. That summer I built the patio at your house? She made me lunch every day.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Well, you were working there--

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: It could have just been a box lunch from the jail.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You built our patio while you  were on the county?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Out in the fresh air, nice gringo lady making you pies--who's gonna sit back in a little jail cell all day? Sheriff Buddy, man. Como el no hay dos. And after that cabron Charley Wade--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I've heard Wade was a bit tough on the Mexicans--

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: He murdered Eladio Cruz. That tough enough for you?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Murdered him?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Chucho Montoya saw it with his own eyes. Shot him in cold blood.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Something wrong?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: They've got my Amado.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Got him here?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Somebody called--something about an electronics store.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'll see what's going on.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I was--I was real sorry about Nando. He was a good fella. We haven't talked since.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: We haven't talked since high school.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah. I'll go check on your boy.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: He's all yours.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Are you okay?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Field trip?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Lunch hour. My next class isn't till nine-thirty.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Want to take a walk?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Your mother still doesn't like me.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I can't name anybody she does like these days.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I see she built a place up here by the river.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: A real palace. She rattles around alone in that thing--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: She's done well for herself--on her own and all--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: So she tells me three times a week.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I thought you got through that pretty well.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: They cooked the whole thing up without asking me.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: People liked him.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Most people did, yeah.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I remember him watching me once. When I was little--before you and I--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I was on the playground with all the other kids, but I thought he was only looking at me. I was afraid he was going to arrest me--he had those eyes, you know--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Weird what you remember.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Your boy, there--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Amado.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Nice-looking kid.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: He hates me.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: With Paloma, it's more like she pities and tolerates me- totally age- appropriate. But Amado--he's--he's never been book-smart. Had a hard time learning to read. Me being a teacher and caring about those things is like an embarrassment--like a betrayal.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Fernando did okay, and he dropped out--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Fernando wasn't pissed off at everybody. He just wanted to fix their cars.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: It might just be the age. I spent my first fifteen years trying to be just like Buddy and the next fifteen trying to give him a heart attack.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: So why did you come back here, Sam?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Got divorced, I wasn't gonna work for my father-in-law anymore. The fellas down here said they'd back me--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: You don't want to be Sheriff.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I got to admit it's not what I thought it'd be. Back When Buddy had it-- hell, I'm just a jailer. Run a 60- room hotel with bars on the windows.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: It can happen so sudden, can't it? Being left out on your own.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You've got your mother, your kids--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: They've got me. Different thing.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I should get back.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Pilar--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Looks real bad if the teacher's late for class. It's really nice to talk with you, Sam.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: We thought we were something, didn't we?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I look at my kids in school--tenth, eleventh graders. That's who we were. Children.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I mean what did we know about anything?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: When Nando died--it was so sudden--I was kind of in shock for awhile. Then I woke up and there was the whole rest of my life and I didn't have any idea what to do with it.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You know the other day, you asked why I came back?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I came back 'cause you were here.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Wow.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: How come it feels the same?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I don't know. It just feels good. Always did.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: So what are we gonna do about this?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: More, I hope.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: How long have you lived here?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Two years.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: There's nothing on the walls. No pictures--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Don't have kids. Other pictures--I don't know--it's nothing I want to look back on.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Like your story is over.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I've felt that way, yeah.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: It isn't. Not by a long shot. He holds her and they lie silently for a moment--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Pilar--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What was your father's name?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Eladio. Eladio. Cruz.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You gonna tell your mother we been seeing each other?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: She'll figure it out sooner or later. I don't have to ask permission anymore, if that's what you mean.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You have any idea when your father died? Eladio?

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Couple months before I was born--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Try a year and a half. He bands her an old snapshot. PILAR looks at it--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I've never seen my mother in a bathing suit before.  Didn't know she owned one.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Buddy bought the cafe for her with money he took from the county. Pilar looks away, struggling not to cry--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: They can't pull this on me. It isn't fair--I don't believe this--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: He paid the hospital bill when you were born. Your mom always calls you "our beautiful daughter" in the letters she wrote to him.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: From the first time I saw you at school--all those years we were married to other people I always felt like we were connected.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I remember thinking you were the one part of my life Buddy didn't have a piece of--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: I'm not having any more children. After Amado, I had some complications-- I can't get pregnant again, if that's what the rule is about--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: If I met you for the first time today, I'd still want to be with you.

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: We start from scratch--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah--

turns.speaker: PILAR
turns.text: Everything that went before, all that stuff, that history--the hell with it, right?

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Hospital says the other kid is in bad shape--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: The shooter local?

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Down from Houston. I think he knew the girl before.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Okay--we'll take a statement from all the GIs before they go back to post. You can get the story from Otis over at the club.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Any poop on the John Doe you found out there today?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Nothin' much. The Rangers put Ben Wetzel on it. Catch you later.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: You're out early.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Haven't seen much of you at the jail lately.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I been working on a few things.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm going over to the other side.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: The Republicans?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No--to Mexico. I've got to talk to somebody.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: They got telephones.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Gotta be in person.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Sam? I--the Committee--you know Jorge and H.L. and all--they asked me--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: They want you to stand for Sheriff next election.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You'd do a good job.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: How 'bout you?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Don't know if I'll still want it.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: I didn't want to be going around your back.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I appreciate you telling me.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You think we need a new jail?

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Well, it's a complicated issue--

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Excellent performance, my friend. The judge was very impressed.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: You don't need to cuff me.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: You been talking so much trash today, you made us think you're a dangerous criminal. Be a good boy, now--

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: You're the one who's a good boy. Man say "fetch" and you fetch--

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Just doing my job.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: White man just using you to keep the Black man down.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: This isn't Houston, my friend. We pretty much running things now. Our good day has come.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: You suckers haven't had a good day since the Alamo.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Don't mind him, Sheriff. Boy's just a bit slow, is all. He don't mean nothin' by it--

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: That the problem, son?  You Slow?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Otis, apologize to the Sheriff--

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: You got him too scared to peep, Sheriff. Maybe if you put that gun up--

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You telling me what to do, Roderick?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: No, Sheriff, I'm just--

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: What's this I see? Is that whiskey in them glasses on the Bar? Roderick, I'm gonna have to cite you for a violation of state law--

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: This is a club, Sheriff--you been in here--

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: And people better clear out of here! Now!

turns.speaker: ZACK
turns.text: Hey Sam. Sorry 'bout that.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What's up?

turns.speaker: ZACK
turns.text: We had about a dozen wets come over just upriver. They ran into one of our posts--it was like a breakshot on a pool table, illegals runnin' every which way.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I haven't seen anybody come by.

turns.speaker: ZACK
turns.text: We'll get 'em--  So you livin' out here now?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah. It's quiet--

turns.speaker: ZACK
turns.text: I heard about that deal for your father--You must be real proud.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: ZACK
turns.text: The stories people tell, he was a real colorful fella--

turns.speaker: WESLEY
turns.text: --but longhorns are hard to come by these days.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You sell much out here?

turns.speaker: WESLEY
turns.text: How am I gonna sell things if nobody comes by? This stretch of road runs between Nowheres and Nothin' Much.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hell of a spot to put a business.

turns.speaker: WESLEY
turns.text: But you don't see much competition, do you?

turns.speaker: WESLEY
turns.text: Buffalo chips. Fella in Santa Fe told me he sells these as fast as the buffalo can squeeze 'em out.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: So when did Buddy leave?

turns.speaker: WESLEY
turns.text: For Frontera? Hell, I can't remember dates no more. I do recall it was after an affair of the heart had gone sour on him. He almost took some poor fella's head off at the Legion in Arroyo Grande, and figured it was time to move on.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You think he killed anybody in Korea?

turns.speaker: WESLEY
turns.text: They don't hand those medals out for hidin'in your foxhole. Would you buy this?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No--

turns.speaker: WESLEY
turns.text: Me neither.
